awd_titl_txt: Quantum Hydrodynamics in Interacting Fermi Gases
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the nearly perfect fluid-flow properties of a special class of ultra-cold atoms, Fermi gases, which are tightly confined in a bowl made of laser light and cooled to temperatures just billionths of a degree above absolute zero. The bowl is turned off to release the ultra-cold atoms into a high vacuum and they are imaged during expansion by laser flash-photography. By just turning a knob in these tabletop experiments, an expanding atom cloud can be made to simulate the behavior of electrons in superconductors, neutrons in neutron stars, or even an exotic state of matter that existed just microseconds after the Big Bang.   The study of these nearly perfect fluids has practical significance in testing theories of high temperature superconductors, which will one day enable energy-saving power transmission, and fundamental significance in testing theories of perfect fluid flow that may have occurred just after the Big Bang. 

The goal of this project is to measure precisely the nearly perfect hydrodynamic transport properties of an ultra-cold atomic Fermi gas. Spin-up and spin-down atoms are made to strongly interact by means of a bias magnetic field, tuned near a collisional (Feshbach) resonance.  A collision between two such clouds produces shock waves as the strongly-interacting clouds bounce off each other. Measurements of the shear viscosity above, at, and below resonance will enable new tests of the lower bound predicted for a perfect fluid using string theory methods.  Studies of scale-invariant flow at resonance will determine the bulk viscosity and test general predictions for scale invariant systems. The experiments cross interdisciplinary boundaries by testing state-of-the-art theory for the transport properties of strongly-correlated matter, which can be simulated in these cold atom experiments, such as high-temperature superconductors, nuclear matter, and quark-gluon plasmas that are created in heavy ion collisions.

por.por_cntn:
This program studies nearly perfect frictionless fluid flow in the expansion of exotic clouds of ultra-cold, atomic Fermi gases. Remarkably, the expansion of these ultra-cold gases, at temperatures less than one tenth of one micro-degree above absolute zero, models the nearly perfect outward flow of the universe microseconds after the Big Bang, when the temperature was two trillion degrees! The same ultra-cold gases test theories of neutron stars and also determine whether it is possible to create super-high temperature superconductors that operate far above room temperature--materials that would enable energy-saving power lines and magnetically levitated trains.

The exotic Fermi gas clouds used in the experiments comprise just a few hundred thousand spin-up and spin-down atoms, which are initially contained in an optical trap or bowl made of focused laser light. An external magnetic field controls the strength of the attraction or repulsion between spin-up and spin-down atoms, which becomes very large when the field is correctly tuned: When a pair of strongly-interacting atom clouds collide, the clouds bounce off each other and shock waves are produced, Fig. 1!

The Fermi gas cloud has another amazing property, it exhibits scale-invariant expansion, as illustrated in Fig. 2. Atoms in an initially trapped cloud act like ``balloons." When the cloud is released from an optical bowl into a vacuum, the balloons expand as the cloud expands and continue to touch, in principle forever. Studying this scale-invariant gas enables exploration of a remarkable conjecture from the string theory community on perfect fluids. The string theory conjecture predicts that the viscosity or stickiness, has a universal minimum, and unifies several fields of physics, connecting the hottest matter in the universe to the coldest matter.

The hottest matter is believed to be the state of the universe just microseconds after the Big Bang, at a temperature of two trillion degrees. At this temperature, where atomic nuclei melt, nuclear constituents (quarks) and gluons (which held them together) are freed to form an exotic soup called a quark-gluon-plasma, or QGP. A QGP has been reproduced by colliding gold atoms together at high energy, using heavy ion colliders, and is very strongly interacting with tremendous density. Yet, counter to intuition, a QGP has been found to have extremely small viscosity, a property of a nearly perfect fluid.

Remarkably, an ultra-cold strongly interacting atomic Fermi gas, at a hundred billionths of a degree, also exhibits nearly perfect fluidity. In fact, the atoms share an amazing common feature with a QGP, which is nineteen orders of magnitude hotter and twenty-five orders of magnitude more dense than the Fermi gas. Both systems exhibit similar ``elliptic" flow, Fig. 3, first observed by our group in 2002, which is a consequence of extremely low viscosity. In our most recent studies of elliptic flow, the local shear viscosity of a strongly interacting Fermi gas was measured from nearly the ground state through the superfluid transition and into the high temperature regime, for the first time. The results show that a QGP and a strongly interacting Fermi gas have similar viscosity, just a few times the conjectured lower bound, when both are expressed in the natural units of Planck's constant times the density, as described in the string theory conjecture on perfect fluids. These new measurements provide benchmarks for state of the art predictions of viscosity in strongly interacting matter.
